verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
verses.comment: Eliphaz, one of Job's friends, responds to Job's complaints. This sets the stage for another cycle of dialogue and debate.

verses.text: Can a man be profitable to God? Surely he who is wise is profitable only to himself.
verses.comment: Eliphaz suggests that man's righteousness does not benefit God, echoing themes addressed further in Job 35:7. The question of man's 'profit' to God points to the Creator's transcendence.

verses.text: Is it any pleasure to the Almighty if you are righteous, or gain to Him if you make your ways blameless?
verses.comment: Eliphaz continues the theme of God's independence from man's moral conduct. Theologically, this raises the point that salvation is initiated by God’s grace, not human merit.

verses.text: Is it because of your reverence that He reproves you, and enters into judgment with you?
verses.comment: Eliphaz accuses Job of suffering due to sin, not righteousness. Suffering as a test or purification is a biblical theme (cf. Heb. 12:5-11).

verses.text: Is not your wickedness great? Are not your sins endless?
verses.comment: Eliphaz makes an accusation without specific evidence—emphasizing that mortal sin separates man from God (Rom. 3:23), needing reconciliation.

verses.text: For you have taken pledges from your brothers without cause, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
verses.comment: Accusations of exploiting the poor echo commands of the Law (Ex. 22:25-27). Justice and mercy for the poor are central biblical virtues.

verses.text: You have given no water to the weary to drink, and you have withheld bread from the hungry.
verses.comment: Feeding the hungry and giving drink to the thirsty are considered works of mercy. Jesus refers to these in Matthew 25, linking mercy with final judgment.

verses.text: But as for the mighty man, he possessed the land, and the honored man lived in it.
verses.comment: Eliphaz alludes to the oppression of the weak by the powerful—a recurrent prophetic theme.

verses.text: You have sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.
verses.comment: The charge here is denial of justice to widows and orphans—God’s champions (cf. Ps. 68:5). True religion upholds their dignity (Jas. 1:27).

verses.text: Therefore snares are all around you, and sudden terror troubles you;
verses.comment: Eliphaz interprets Job’s suffering as divine retribution for hidden sin, a view later challenged by God Himself (Job 42:7).

verses.text: or darkness, that you cannot see, and a flood of waters covers you.
verses.comment: Imagery of overwhelming disaster often symbolizes judgment and spiritual testing.

verses.text: Is not God in the heights of heaven? See how high the stars are, how lofty they are!
verses.comment: God’s transcendence is highlighted. The separation between God’s ways and man’s ways is a profound biblical truth.

verses.text: Yet you say, ‘What does God know? Can He judge through deep darkness?’
verses.comment: Eliphaz attributes skepticism to Job. God’s ability to judge is absolute; hidden sins will not escape His sight.

verses.text: Thick clouds are a covering to Him, so that He does not see; and He walks on the circle of the heavens.
verses.comment: Eliphaz seems to caricature Job's perspective: that God is distant or uninvolved—contrary to the biblical doctrine of God’s omnipresence.

verses.text: Will you keep to the old way that wicked men have walked?
verses.comment: The reference to the 'old way' invokes the tradition of the two ways: the way of the righteous versus the way of sinners (Ps. 1).

verses.text: They were snatched away before their time; their foundations were washed away by a flood.
verses.comment: Reference to flood as divine judgment recalls the story of Noah. God’s judgments are swift and just.

verses.text: They said to God, ‘Depart from us,’ and, ‘What can the Almighty do to us?’
verses.comment: Willful rebellion against God leads to separation from Him—a central biblical warning.

verses.text: Yet He filled their houses with good things— but the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
verses.comment: God's patience allows blessings to fall even on the wicked (cf. Matt. 5:45). Yet ultimately, alignment with God’s will is what lasts.

verses.text: The righteous see it and are glad; the innocent mock them, saying:
verses.comment: God’s eventual justice brings vindication for the righteous and exposes the folly of sin.

verses.text: ‘Surely our adversaries are cut off, and fire has consumed what they left behind.’
verses.comment: Imagery of fire as judgment recurs in both Old and New Testaments, especially with respect to ultimate justice (cf. 2 Pet. 3:7).

verses.text: Now submit yourself to God and be at peace; by this good will come to you.
verses.comment: Submission to God as the path to true peace and blessing is a cornerstone of biblical spirituality. The call to ‘be at peace’ echoes the invitation to conversion and reconciliation.

verses.text: Receive instruction from His mouth, and lay up His words in your heart.
verses.comment: Laying up God’s word in the heart signifies both literal study and spiritual meditation—a continual process in the journey toward holiness.

verses.text: If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored. If you remove injustice from your tents,
verses.comment: The language of repentance and restoration points to the possibility of reconciliation with God and the need for removing sin—the practice of ongoing conversion.

verses.text: then lay your gold in the dust, and the gold of Ophir among the stones of the brooks,
verses.comment: Attachment to wealth must be surrendered for true spiritual riches (cf. Matt. 6:19–21).

verses.text: then the Almighty will be your gold and your precious silver.
verses.comment: God Himself is the true treasure; union with Him surpasses all earthly riches.

verses.text: For then you will delight yourself in the Almighty and lift up your face to God.
verses.comment: Delighting in God is central to spiritual life—echoed in Christ’s command to love God with all your heart (Matt. 22:37).

verses.text: You will pray to Him, and He will hear you, and you will pay your vows.
verses.comment: Prayer and fulfilling vows show active faith; the idea of vows is retained in New Testament practice, seen in various Christian commitments.

verses.text: You will decide on a matter, and it will be established for you, and light will shine on your ways.
verses.comment: Righteousness produces clarity and blessing—a biblical encouragement to commit one’s ways to God for His guidance.

verses.text: For when they are humbled and you say, ‘Lift them up!’ then He will save the lowly person.
verses.comment: God’s preference for the humble is a key theme, fulfilled in Christ (cf. Phil. 2:5-11). Intercession for others, seen here, continues in the life of the Church.

verses.text: He will deliver even one who is not innocent, who will be delivered through the cleanness of your hands.
verses.comment: This verse hints at the powerful efficacy of the prayers and righteousness of the faithful on behalf of others. The spiritual value of mediation and intercession is fulfilled in Christ, who is the one Mediator (1 Tim. 2:5), but is also reflected in the prayers of the saints throughout history.
